1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Finite.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     5â†’
     6â†’open Filter Set
     7â†’
     8â†’noncomputable section
     9â†’
    10â†’/-!
    11â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #157
    12â†’
    13â†’Does there exist an infinite Sidon set which is an asymptotic basis of order 3?
    14â†’
    15â†’Answered YES by Pilatte [Pi23].
    16â†’-/
    17â†’
    18â†’/-- An infinite set A âŠ† â„• is a Sidon set (Bâ‚‚ set) if all pairwise sums
    19â†’    are distinct: whenever a + b = c + d with a, b, c, d âˆˆ A, we have
    20â†’    {a, b} = {c, d} as multisets (i.e. either a = c and b = d, or a = d and b = c). -/
    21â†’def IsInfiniteSidonSet (A : Set â„•) : Prop :=
    22â†’  Set.Infinite A âˆ§
    23â†’  âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆ€ b âˆˆ A, âˆ€ c âˆˆ A, âˆ€ d âˆˆ A,
    24â†’    a + b = c + d â†’ (a = c âˆ§ b = d) âˆ¨ (a = d âˆ§ b = c)
    25â†’
    26â†’/-- A set A âŠ† â„• is an asymptotic basis of order 3 if every sufficiently
    27â†’    large natural number can be represented as a sum of (exactly) 3 elements
    28â†’    (with repetition allowed) from A. -/
    29â†’def IsAsymptoticBasisOrder3 (A : Set â„•) : Prop :=
    30â†’  âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop, âˆƒ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ b âˆˆ A, âˆƒ c âˆˆ A, n = a + b + c
    31â†’
    32â†’/--
    33â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #157 [ESS94, Er94b]:
    34â†’
    35â†’Does there exist an infinite Sidon set which is an asymptotic basis of order 3?
    36â†’
    37â†’A set A âŠ† â„• is a Sidon set if all pairwise sums a + b (a, b âˆˆ A) are distinct.
    38â†’A set A is an asymptotic basis of order 3 if every sufficiently large integer
    39â†’is the sum of 3 elements from A.
    40â†’
    41â†’Answered YES by Pilatte [Pi23].
    42â†’
    43â†’Formalized as: there exists an infinite set A âŠ† â„• that is a Sidon set and
    44â†’an asymptotic basis of order 3.
    45â†’-/
    46â†’theorem erdos_problem_157 :
    47â†’    âˆƒ A : Set â„•, IsInfiniteSidonSet A âˆ§ IsAsymptoticBasisOrder3 A :=
    48â†’  sorry
    49â†’
    50â†’end
    51â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real
     4â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     5â†’
     6â†’open Filter Real Finset Topology
     7â†’
     8â†’noncomputable section
     9â†’
    10â†’/-!
    11â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #156
    12â†’
    13â†’Does there exist a maximal Sidon set $A \subset \{1, \ldots, N\}$ of size $O(N^{1/3})$?
    14â†’
    15â†’A question of ErdÅ‘s, SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy, and SÃ³s [ESS94]. It is easy to prove that the greedy
    16â†’construction of a maximal Sidon set in $\{1, \ldots, N\}$ has size $\gg N^{1/3}$.
    17â†’Ruzsa [Ru98b] constructed a maximal Sidon set of size $\ll (N \log N)^{1/3}$, but
    18â†’whether $O(N^{1/3})$ is achievable remains open.
    19â†’-/
    20â†’
    21â†’/-- A finite set of natural numbers is a Sidon set (also called a Bâ‚‚ set) if all
    22â†’    pairwise sums a + b (allowing a = b) are distinct: whenever a + b = c + d
    23â†’    with a, b, c, d âˆˆ A, we have {a, b} = {c, d} as multisets. -/
    24â†’def IsSidonSet (A : Finset â„•) : Prop :=
    25â†’  âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆ€ b âˆˆ A, âˆ€ c âˆˆ A, âˆ€ d âˆˆ A,
    26â†’    a + b = c + d â†’ (a = c âˆ§ b = d) âˆ¨ (a = d âˆ§ b = c)
    27â†’
    28â†’/-- A Sidon set A âŠ† {0, ..., N-1} is maximal (in {0, ..., N-1}) if no element of
    29â†’    {0, ..., N-1} \ A can be added to A while preserving the Sidon property. -/
    30â†’def IsMaximalSidonSet (N : â„•) (A : Finset â„•) : Prop :=
    31â†’  A âŠ† Finset.range N âˆ§
    32â†’  IsSidonSet A âˆ§
    33â†’  âˆ€ n âˆˆ Finset.range N, n âˆ‰ A â†’ Â¬IsSidonSet (insert n A)
    34â†’
    35â†’/--
    36â†’ErdÅ‘sâ€“SÃ¡rkÃ¶zyâ€“SÃ³s Conjecture (Problem #156) [ESS94]:
    37â†’
    38â†’Does there exist a maximal Sidon set $A \subset \{1, \ldots, N\}$ of size $O(N^{1/3})$?
    39â†’
    40â†’This is the conjecture that the answer is YES.
    41â†’
    42â†’The greedy algorithm produces a maximal Sidon set of size $\gg N^{1/3}$ (this is known).
    43â†’Ruzsa [Ru98b] constructed a maximal Sidon set of size $\ll (N \log N)^{1/3}$, which is
    44â†’close but does not reach $O(N^{1/3})$.
    45â†’
    46â†’Formalized as: there exists a constant $C > 0$ such that for all sufficiently large $N$,
    47â†’there exists a maximal Sidon set $A \subseteq \{0, \ldots, N-1\}$ with
    48â†’$|A| \leq C \cdot N^{1/3}$.
    49â†’-/
    50â†’theorem erdos_problem_156 :
    51â†’    âˆƒ C : â„, 0 < C âˆ§
    52â†’      âˆ€á¶  N : â„• in atTop,
    53â†’        âˆƒ A : Finset â„•, IsMaximalSidonSet N A âˆ§
    54â†’          (A.card : â„) â‰¤ C * (N : â„) ^ ((1 : â„) / 3) :=
    55â†’  sorry
    56â†’
    57â†’end
    58â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.NAry
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Sqrt
     5â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Filter Real Finset Topology
     9â†’
    10â†’noncomputable section
    11â†’
    12â†’/-- A finite set of natural numbers is a Sidon set (also called a Bâ‚‚ set) if all
    13â†’    pairwise sums a + b (allowing a = b) are distinct: whenever a + b = c + d
    14â†’    with a, b, c, d âˆˆ A, we have {a, b} = {c, d} as multisets. Equivalently,
    15â†’    all differences a - b with a â‰  b and a, b âˆˆ A are distinct. -/
    16â†’def IsSidonSet (A : Finset â„•) : Prop :=
    17â†’  âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆ€ b âˆˆ A, âˆ€ c âˆˆ A, âˆ€ d âˆˆ A,
    18â†’    a + b = c + d â†’ (a = c âˆ§ b = d) âˆ¨ (a = d âˆ§ b = c)
    19â†’
    20â†’/-- The sumset A + A = {a + b | a, b âˆˆ A}. -/
    21â†’def sumset (A : Finset â„•) : Finset â„• := Finset.imageâ‚‚ (Â· + Â·) A A
    22â†’
    23â†’/-- The fraction of elements in a finite set of naturals that are congruent to r modulo m. -/
    24â†’noncomputable def modFraction (m r : â„•) (S : Finset â„•) : â„ :=
    25â†’  ((S.filter (fun n => n % m = r)).card : â„) / (S.card : â„)
    26â†’
    27â†’/--
    28â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #154 [ESS94]:
    29â†’
    30â†’Let A âŠ‚ {1,...,N} be a Sidon set with |A| âˆ¼ N^(1/2). Must A + A be
    31â†’well-distributed over all small moduli? In particular, must about half
    32â†’the elements of A+A be even and half odd?
    33â†’
    34â†’Proved in the affirmative. LindstrÃ¶m [Li98] showed that A itself is
    35â†’well-distributed modulo small integers (e.g. |A âˆ© {evens}| â‰ˆ |A|/2),
    36â†’subsequently strengthened by Kolountzakis [Ko99]. The extension to A + A
    37â†’follows immediately from the Sidon property: if A has e even and o odd
    38â†’elements, then A + A has exactly e*(e+1)/2 + o*(o+1)/2 even elements
    39â†’and e*o odd elements (all distinct by the Sidon property), and the
    40â†’distribution is approximately 1/2 each when e â‰ˆ o â‰ˆ |A|/2.
    41â†’
    42â†’Formalized as: for any sequence (Aâ‚™)â‚™ of Sidon sets Aâ‚™ âŠ‚ {0,...,n}
    43â†’with |Aâ‚™| / âˆšn â†’ 1 as n â†’ âˆ, and any fixed modulus m â‰¥ 1 and
    44â†’residue 0 â‰¤ r < m, the fraction of elements of Aâ‚™ + Aâ‚™ in residue
    45â†’class r mod m tends to 1/m.
    46â†’-/
    47â†’theorem erdos_problem_154 :
    48â†’    âˆ€ (A : â„• â†’ Finset â„•),
    49â†’      (âˆ€ n, IsSidonSet (A n)) â†’
    50â†’      (âˆ€ n, (A n) âŠ† Finset.range (n + 1)) â†’
    51â†’      Tendsto (fun n => ((A n).card : â„) / Real.sqrt n) atTop (ğ“ 1) â†’
    52â†’      âˆ€ (m : â„•), 1 â‰¤ m â†’
    53â†’        âˆ€ r < m,
    54â†’          Tendsto (fun n => modFraction m r (sumset (A n))) atTop (ğ“ (1 / (m : â„))) :=
    55â†’  sorry
    56â†’
    57â†’end
    58â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Connectivity.Connected
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     5â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real
     7â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     8â†’
     9â†’open SimpleGraph Real Filter
    10â†’
    11â†’noncomputable section
    12â†’
    13â†’/-!
    14â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #150
    15â†’
    16â†’A minimal cut of a graph is a minimal set of vertices whose removal disconnects
    17â†’the graph. Let c(n) be the maximum number of minimal cuts a graph on n vertices
    18â†’can have. Does c(n)^(1/n) â†’ Î± for some Î± < 2?
    19â†’
    20â†’Asked by ErdÅ‘s and NeÅ¡etÅ™il. Seymour observed that c(3m+2) â‰¥ 3^m via m
    21â†’independent paths of length 4 joining two vertices.
    22â†’
    23â†’Proved by BradaÄ [Br24]: the limit Î± = lim c(n)^(1/n) exists and
    24â†’Î± â‰¤ 2^H(1/3) = 1.8899... < 2, where H(Â·) is the binary entropy function.
    25â†’This confirms the conjecture. BradaÄ conjectures the true value is Î± = 3^(1/3).
    26â†’-/
    27â†’
    28â†’/-- A set S of vertices is a vertex separator of G if the subgraph induced by
    29â†’    the complement V \ S is not connected. -/
    30â†’def IsVertexSeparator {n : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) (S : Finset (Fin n)) : Prop :=
    31â†’  Â¬(G.induce ((S : Set (Fin n))á¶œ)).Connected
    32â†’
    33â†’/-- S is a minimal vertex cut of G if S is a vertex separator and no proper
    34â†’    subset of S is also a vertex separator. -/
    35â†’def IsMinimalVertexCut {n : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) (S : Finset (Fin n)) : Prop :=
    36â†’  IsVertexSeparator G S âˆ§
    37â†’  âˆ€ T : Finset (Fin n), T âŠ‚ S â†’ Â¬IsVertexSeparator G T
    38â†’
    39â†’/-- The number of minimal vertex cuts of G. -/
    40â†’noncomputable def numMinimalVertexCuts {n : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) : â„• :=
    41â†’  Set.ncard { S : Finset (Fin n) | IsMinimalVertexCut G S }
    42â†’
    43â†’/-- c(n) is the maximum number of minimal vertex cuts over all connected simple
    44â†’    graphs on n vertices. -/
    45â†’noncomputable def c (n : â„•) : â„• :=
    46â†’  sSup { k : â„• | âˆƒ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n), G.Connected âˆ§
    47â†’    numMinimalVertexCuts G = k }
    48â†’
    49â†’/--
    50â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #150 [Er88] (asked by ErdÅ‘s and NeÅ¡etÅ™il):
    51â†’Let c(n) be the maximum number of minimal vertex cuts in a graph on n vertices.
    52â†’Does c(n)^(1/n) â†’ Î± for some Î± < 2?
    53â†’
    54â†’Proved by BradaÄ [Br24]: the limit Î± = lim c(n)^(1/n) exists and
    55â†’Î± â‰¤ 2^H(1/3) = 1.8899... < 2, where H(Â·) is the binary entropy function.
    56â†’Seymour's construction gives c(3m+2) â‰¥ 3^m, so Î± â‰¥ 3^(1/3) â‰ˆ 1.442.
    57â†’BradaÄ conjectures that the true value is Î± = 3^(1/3).
    58â†’-/
    59â†’theorem erdos_problem_150 :
    60â†’    âˆƒ Î± : â„, Î± < 2 âˆ§
    61â†’      Tendsto (fun n : â„• => (c n : â„) ^ ((1 : â„) / (n : â„)))
    62â†’        atTop (nhds Î±) :=
    63â†’  sorry
    64â†’
    65â†’end
    66â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic

     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open BigOperators Real Filter
     9â†’
    10â†’/-!
    11â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #148
    12â†’
    13â†’Let F(k) be the number of solutions to 1 = 1/nâ‚ + â‹¯ + 1/nâ‚– where
    14â†’1 â‰¤ nâ‚ < nâ‚‚ < â‹¯ < nâ‚– are distinct positive integers.
    15â†’Find good estimates for F(k).
    16â†’
    17â†’The current best known bounds are
    18â†’  2^{c^{k/log k}} â‰¤ F(k) â‰¤ câ‚€^{(1/5 + o(1))Â·2^k}
    19â†’where c > 0 is some absolute constant and câ‚€ = 1.26408â‹¯ is the Vardi constant.
    20â†’The lower bound is due to Konyagin [Ko14] and the upper bound to
    21â†’Elsholtz and Planitzer [ElPl21].
    22â†’-/
    23â†’
    24â†’/-- F(k) is the number of k-element sets of positive integers
    25â†’    whose unit fractions sum to 1: 1/nâ‚ + â‹¯ + 1/nâ‚– = 1. -/
    26â†’noncomputable def egyptianFractionCount (k : â„•) : â„• :=
    27â†’  Set.ncard {S : Finset â„• | S.card = k âˆ§ (âˆ€ n âˆˆ S, 0 < n) âˆ§
    28â†’    âˆ‘ n âˆˆ S, (1 : â„š) / (n : â„š) = 1}
    29â†’
    30â†’/-- Konyagin lower bound [Ko14]:
    31â†’    There exists an absolute constant c > 0 such that
    32â†’    2^{c^{k/log k}} â‰¤ F(k) for all sufficiently large k. -/
    33â†’theorem egyptianFractionCount_konyagin_lower_bound :
    34â†’    âˆƒ c : â„, 0 < c âˆ§ âˆ€á¶  k : â„• in atTop,
    35â†’      (2 : â„) ^ (c ^ ((k : â„) / Real.log k)) â‰¤
    36â†’        (egyptianFractionCount k : â„) :=
    37â†’  sorry
    38â†’
    39â†’/-- Elsholtzâ€“Planitzer upper bound [ElPl21]:
    40â†’    There exists a constant câ‚€ > 1 (the Vardi constant, câ‚€ â‰ˆ 1.26408) such that
    41â†’    for every Îµ > 0, F(k) â‰¤ câ‚€^{(1/5 + Îµ)Â·2^k} for all sufficiently large k. -/
    42â†’theorem egyptianFractionCount_elsholtz_planitzer_upper_bound :
    43â†’    âˆƒ câ‚€ : â„, 1 < câ‚€ âˆ§ âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ âˆ€á¶  k : â„• in atTop,
    44â†’      (egyptianFractionCount k : â„) â‰¤
    45â†’        câ‚€ ^ ((1 / 5 + Îµ) * (2 : â„) ^ (k : â„•)) :=
    46â†’  sorry
    47â†’
    48â†’/-- ErdÅ‘s Problem #148 [ErGr80, p.32]:
    49â†’    Find good estimates for F(k), the number of representations of 1
    50â†’    as a sum of exactly k distinct unit fractions.
    51â†’
    52â†’    The open problem is to close the gap between the known bounds. This
    53â†’    conjecture asserts that the correct order of magnitude is exponential
    54â†’    in 2^k: there exist constants 1 < câ‚ â‰¤ câ‚‚ such that
    55â†’    câ‚^{2^k} â‰¤ F(k) â‰¤ câ‚‚^{2^k} for all sufficiently large k.
    56â†’    In particular, the Konyagin lower bound should be improvable to
    57â†’    exponential in 2^k to match the Elsholtzâ€“Planitzer upper bound. -/
    58â†’theorem erdos_problem_148 :
    59â†’    âˆƒ câ‚ câ‚‚ : â„, 1 < câ‚ âˆ§ 1 < câ‚‚ âˆ§ âˆ€á¶  k : â„• in atTop,
    60â†’      câ‚ ^ ((2 : â„) ^ (k : â„•)) â‰¤ (egyptianFractionCount k : â„) âˆ§
    61â†’      (egyptianFractionCount k : â„) â‰¤ câ‚‚ ^ ((2 : â„) ^ (k : â„•)) :=
    62â†’  sorry
    63â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.Basic

    10â†’/-- A positive integer n has two divisors dâ‚, dâ‚‚ with dâ‚ < dâ‚‚ < 2 * dâ‚. -/
    11â†’def HasCloseConsecutiveDivisors (n : â„•) : Prop :=
    12â†’  âˆƒ dâ‚ dâ‚‚ : â„•, dâ‚ âˆ£ n âˆ§ dâ‚‚ âˆ£ n âˆ§ dâ‚ < dâ‚‚ âˆ§ dâ‚‚ < 2 * dâ‚
    13â†’
    14â†’/--
    15â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #144 [Er61, Er77c, Er79, Er79e, ErGr80, Er81h, Er82e, Er85e, Er97c, Er98]:
    16â†’The density of integers which have two divisors dâ‚, dâ‚‚ such that dâ‚ < dâ‚‚ < 2*dâ‚
    17â†’exists and is equal to 1.
    18â†’
    19â†’Formally, writing A(N) for the number of integers n with 1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ N which have
    20â†’two divisors dâ‚ < dâ‚‚ < 2*dâ‚, we have A(N)/N â†’ 1 as N â†’ âˆ.
    21â†’
    22â†’Proved by Maier and Tenenbaum [MaTe84].
    23â†’-/
    24â†’theorem erdos_problem_144 :
    25â†’    Tendsto
    26â†’      (fun N : â„• =>
    27â†’        (((Finset.range N).filter (fun n => HasCloseConsecutiveDivisors (n + 1))).card : â„) /
    28â†’        (N : â„))
    29â†’      atTop
    30â†’      (ğ“ (1 : â„)) :=

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Real Filter
     9â†’
    10â†’noncomputable section
    11â†’
    12â†’/-- A finite set S âŠ† â„• is 3-AP-free if it contains no non-trivial 3-term
    13â†’    arithmetic progression: for all a, b, c âˆˆ S satisfying a + c = 2 * b,
    14â†’    we have a = b (which forces a = b = c, i.e., the progression is trivial). -/
    15â†’def IsThreeAPFree (S : Finset â„•) : Prop :=
    16â†’  âˆ€ a âˆˆ S, âˆ€ b âˆˆ S, âˆ€ c âˆˆ S, a + c = 2 * b â†’ a = b
    17â†’
    18â†’/-- râ‚ƒ(N) is the maximum size of a 3-AP-free subset of {1, ..., N}. -/
    19â†’noncomputable def r3 (N : â„•) : â„• :=
    20â†’  sSup { k : â„• | âˆƒ S : Finset â„•,
    21â†’    (âˆ€ x âˆˆ S, 1 â‰¤ x âˆ§ x â‰¤ N) âˆ§
    22â†’    IsThreeAPFree S âˆ§
    23â†’    S.card = k }
    24â†’
    25â†’/--
    26â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #140 [ErGr80, Er81, Er97c]:
    27â†’Let râ‚ƒ(N) be the size of the largest subset of {1, ..., N} containing no
    28â†’non-trivial 3-term arithmetic progression. Then râ‚ƒ(N) â‰ª N / (log N)^C
    29â†’for every C > 0.
    30â†’
    31â†’Formally: for every C > 0 there exists a constant K > 0 such that
    32â†’  râ‚ƒ(N) â‰¤ K * N / (log N)^C  for all sufficiently large N.
    33â†’
    34â†’Proved by Kelley and Meka [KeMe23].
    35â†’-/
    36â†’theorem erdos_problem_140 :
    37â†’    âˆ€ C : â„, 0 < C â†’
    38â†’    âˆƒ K : â„, 0 < K âˆ§
    39â†’    âˆ€á¶  N : â„• in atTop,
    40â†’      (r3 N : â„) â‰¤ K * (N : â„) / (Real.log (N : â„)) ^ C :=
    41â†’  sorry
    42â†’
    43â†’end
    44â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Prod
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     6â†’
     7â†’open Classical Filter
     8â†’
     9â†’noncomputable section
    10â†’
    11â†’/-!
    12â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #136
    13â†’
    14â†’Let f(n) be the smallest number of colours required to colour the edges of K_n
    15â†’such that every K_4 contains at least 5 colours. Determine the size of f(n).
    16â†’
    17â†’Asked by ErdÅ‘s and GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s, who proved that (5/6)(n-1) < f(n) < n and that
    18â†’f(9) = 8. ErdÅ‘s believed the upper bound is closer to the truth. In fact the
    19â†’lower bound is: Bennett, Cushman, Dudek, and Pralat [BCDP22] proved that
    20â†’f(n) ~ (5/6)n. Joos and Mubayi [JoMu22] found a shorter proof.
    21â†’-/
    22â†’
    23â†’/-- An edge coloring of K_n with colors from Fin k, represented as a function
    24â†’    on ordered pairs of vertices. -/
    25â†’def EdgeColoring (n k : â„•) : Type := Fin n â†’ Fin n â†’ Fin k
    26â†’
    27â†’/-- The set of distinct colors used on edges within vertex subset S
    28â†’    under coloring Ï‡ (using offDiag to enumerate all ordered pairs of
    29â†’    distinct vertices in S). -/
    30â†’noncomputable def edgeColors {n k : â„•} (Ï‡ : EdgeColoring n k)
    31â†’    (S : Finset (Fin n)) : Finset (Fin k) :=
    32â†’  S.offDiag.image (fun p => Ï‡ p.1 p.2)
    33â†’
    34â†’/-- A coloring Ï‡ of K_n is Kâ‚„-five-colored if every 4-element vertex subset
    35â†’    has at least 5 distinct colors on its edges. -/
    36â†’def IsK4FiveColored {n k : â„•} (Ï‡ : EdgeColoring n k) : Prop :=
    37â†’  âˆ€ S : Finset (Fin n), S.card = 4 â†’ 5 â‰¤ (edgeColors Ï‡ S).card
    38â†’
    39â†’/-- f(n): the minimum number of colors k for which there exists a
    40â†’    Kâ‚„-five-colored edge coloring of K_n. -/
    41â†’noncomputable def f (n : â„•) : â„• :=
    42â†’  sInf {k : â„• | âˆƒ Ï‡ : EdgeColoring n k, IsK4FiveColored Ï‡}
    43â†’
    44â†’/--
    45â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #136 â€“ ErdÅ‘sâ€“GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s bounds [Er97b]:
    46â†’For all sufficiently large n, (5/6)(n-1) < f(n) < n.
    47â†’ErdÅ‘s and GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s also established the exact value f(9) = 8.
    48â†’-/
    49â†’theorem erdos136_bounds :
    50â†’    âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    51â†’      (5 : â„) / 6 * ((n : â„) - 1) < (f n : â„) âˆ§ (f n : â„) < (n : â„) :=
    52â†’  sorry
    53â†’
    54â†’/--
    55â†’Special value: f(9) = 8, proved by ErdÅ‘s and GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s [Er97b].
    56â†’-/
    57â†’theorem erdos136_f9 : f 9 = 8 :=
    58â†’  sorry
    59â†’
    60â†’/--
    61â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #136 â€“ asymptotic result
    62â†’(Bennettâ€“Cushmanâ€“Dudekâ€“Pralat [BCDP22]; shorter proof by Joosâ€“Mubayi [JoMu22]):
    63â†’f(n) ~ (5/6)n. That is, for every Îµ > 0 and all sufficiently large n,
    64â†’|(f n) / n - 5/6| < Îµ.
    65â†’-/
    66â†’theorem erdos136_asymptotic :
    67â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    68â†’      |(f n : â„) / (n : â„) - 5 / 6| < Îµ :=
    69â†’  sorry
    70â†’
    71â†’end
    72â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     3â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Classical SimpleGraph Filter Real
     9â†’
    10â†’noncomputable section
    11â†’
    12â†’/-!
    13â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #134
    14â†’
    15â†’Let Îµ, Î´ > 0 and n be sufficiently large in terms of Îµ and Î´. Let G be a
    16â†’triangle-free graph on n vertices with maximum degree < n^(1/2 - Îµ).
    17â†’
    18â†’Can G be made into a triangle-free graph with diameter 2 by adding at most Î´nÂ² edges?
    19â†’
    20â†’Asked by ErdÅ‘s and GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s, who proved this is the case when G has maximum degree
    21â†’â‰ª log n / log log n. A construction of Simonovits shows the conjecture fails if the
    22â†’maximum degree bound is relaxed to â‰¤ Cn^(1/2) for a large enough constant C.
    23â†’
    24â†’Proved in the affirmative by Alon [Al94]: a triangle-free graph on n vertices with
    25â†’maximum degree < n^(1/2 - Îµ) can be made into a triangle-free graph with diameter 2
    26â†’by adding at most O(n^(2 - Îµ)) edges.
    27â†’-/
    28â†’
    29â†’/-- A graph has diameter at most 2 if every pair of distinct vertices is
    30â†’    either adjacent or shares a common neighbor. -/
    31â†’def HasDiameterAtMostTwo {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    32â†’  âˆ€ u v : V, u â‰  v â†’ G.Adj u v âˆ¨ âˆƒ w : V, G.Adj u w âˆ§ G.Adj w v
    33â†’
    34â†’/--
    35â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #134 [Er97b] (proved by Alon [Al94]):
    36â†’
    37â†’For every Îµ, Î´ > 0 and all sufficiently large n, every triangle-free graph on
    38â†’n vertices with maximum degree < n^(1/2 - Îµ) can be extended to a triangle-free
    39â†’graph with diameter â‰¤ 2 by adding at most Î´nÂ² edges.
    40â†’-/
    41â†’theorem erdos134 :
    42â†’    âˆ€ Îµ Î´ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ 0 < Î´ â†’ âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    43â†’      âˆ€ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    44â†’        G.CliqueFree 3 â†’
    45â†’        (âˆ€ v : Fin n, (G.degree v : â„) < (n : â„) ^ ((1 : â„) / 2 - Îµ)) â†’
    46â†’        âˆƒ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    47â†’          G â‰¤ H âˆ§ H.CliqueFree 3 âˆ§ HasDiameterAtMostTwo H âˆ§
    48â†’          (H.edgeFinset.card : â„) - (G.edgeFinset.card : â„) â‰¤ Î´ * (n : â„) ^ 2 :=
    49â†’  sorry
    50â†’
    51â†’/--
    52â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #134 (Alon's strong form [Al94]):
    53â†’
    54â†’For every Îµ > 0 there exists C > 0 such that for all sufficiently large n,
    55â†’every triangle-free graph on n vertices with maximum degree < n^(1/2 - Îµ)
    56â†’can be extended to a triangle-free graph with diameter â‰¤ 2 by adding at
    57â†’most C Â· n^(2 - Îµ) edges.
    58â†’-/
    59â†’theorem erdos134_alon :
    60â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ âˆƒ C : â„, 0 < C âˆ§ âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    61â†’      âˆ€ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    62â†’        G.CliqueFree 3 â†’
    63â†’        (âˆ€ v : Fin n, (G.degree v : â„) < (n : â„) ^ ((1 : â„) / 2 - Îµ)) â†’
    64â†’        âˆƒ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    65â†’          G â‰¤ H âˆ§ H.CliqueFree 3 âˆ§ HasDiameterAtMostTwo H âˆ§
    66â†’          (H.edgeFinset.card : â„) - (G.edgeFinset.card : â„) â‰¤ C * (n : â„) ^ (2 - Îµ) :=
    67â†’  sorry
    68â†’
    69â†’end
    70â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Sqrt
     5â†’import Mathlib.Data.Fintype.Card
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open SimpleGraph Filter
     9â†’
    10â†’/-!
    11â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #133
    12â†’
    13â†’Let $f(n)$ be minimal such that every triangle-free graph $G$ with $n$ vertices
    14â†’and diameter $2$ contains a vertex with degree $\geq f(n)$.
    15â†’
    16â†’What is the order of growth of $f(n)$? Does $f(n)/\sqrt{n}\to \infty$?
    17â†’
    18â†’This was asked by ErdÅ‘s and Pach. The answer to the second question is **No**
    19â†’(the problem is marked DISPROVED): $f(n) = \Theta(\sqrt{n})$.
    20â†’
    21â†’Key results:
    22â†’- Lower bound: $f(n) \geq \lfloor\sqrt{n-1}\rfloor$ from the Moore bound.
    23â†’  A graph with max degree $d$ and diameter $\leq 2$ has at most $d^2+1$ vertices.
    24â†’- Hansonâ€“Seyffarth [HaSe84]: $f(n) \leq (\sqrt{2}+o(1))\sqrt{n}$, via a Cayley
    25â†’  graph on $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ using a symmetric complete sum-free set.
    26â†’- FÃ¼rediâ€“Seress [FuSe94]: $f(n) \leq (\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}+o(1))\sqrt{n}$.
    27â†’- Alon: a construction giving $f(n) \ll \sqrt{n\log n}$ (superseded by the above).
    28â†’- The precise constant is unknown; Alon conjectures $f(n) \sim \sqrt{n}$.
    29â†’-/
    30â†’
    31â†’/-- A graph $G$ contains a triangle if there are three mutually adjacent vertices. -/
    32â†’def HasTriangle {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    33â†’  âˆƒ a b c : V, G.Adj a b âˆ§ G.Adj b c âˆ§ G.Adj a c
    34â†’
    35â†’/-- A graph has diameter at most 2 if every pair of distinct vertices is
    36â†’    either directly adjacent or has a common neighbor. -/
    37â†’def HasDiameterAtMostTwo {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    38â†’  âˆ€ u v : V, u â‰  v â†’ G.Adj u v âˆ¨ âˆƒ w : V, G.Adj u w âˆ§ G.Adj w v
    39â†’
    40â†’/-- $\mathrm{erdos133\_f}(n)$ is the minimum $k$ such that every triangle-free
    41â†’    graph on $n$ vertices with diameter at most $2$ contains a vertex of degree
    42â†’    at least $k$.  Equivalently, it is the minimum maximum-degree over all such
    43â†’    graphs.  When no such graph exists (e.g.\ for $n = 1$) the infimum of the
    44â†’    empty set is $0$. -/
    45â†’noncomputable def erdos133_f (n : â„•) : â„• :=
    46â†’  sInf { k : â„• | âˆ€ (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) [DecidableRel G.Adj],
    47â†’    Â¬HasTriangle G â†’ HasDiameterAtMostTwo G â†’
    48â†’    âˆƒ v : Fin n, k â‰¤ G.degree v }
    49â†’
    50â†’/--
    51â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #133 (Moore bound lower bound) [ErPa90]:
    52â†’$f(n) \geq \lfloor\sqrt{n-1}\rfloor$ for all $n \geq 1$.
    53â†’
    54â†’Proof sketch: a graph with max degree $d$ and diameter $\leq 2$ has at most
    55â†’$1 + d + d(d-1) = d^2+1$ vertices.  Hence if $G$ is triangle-free on $n$
    56â†’vertices with diameter $\leq 2$ and max degree $d$, then $n \leq d^2+1$,
    57â†’giving $d \geq \sqrt{n-1}$.
    58â†’-/
    59â†’theorem erdos133_lower_bound (n : â„•) (hn : 1 â‰¤ n) :
    60â†’    Nat.sqrt (n - 1) â‰¤ erdos133_f n :=
    61â†’  sorry
    62â†’
    63â†’/--
    64â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #133 (Hansonâ€“Seyffarth upper bound [HaSe84]):
    65â†’$f(n) \leq (\sqrt{2} + o(1))\sqrt{n}$.
    66â†’
    67â†’For every $\varepsilon > 0$ and all sufficiently large $n$, there exists a
    68â†’triangle-free graph on $n$ vertices with diameter $\leq 2$ and max degree
    69â†’$\leq (\sqrt{2} + \varepsilon)\sqrt{n}$.  The construction is a Cayley graph on
    70â†’$\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ with a symmetric complete sum-free generating set of
    71â†’size $\sim \sqrt{n}$.
    72â†’-/
    73â†’theorem erdos133_upper_bound :
    74â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    75â†’      (erdos133_f n : â„) â‰¤ (Real.sqrt 2 + Îµ) * Real.sqrt n :=
    76â†’  sorry
    77â†’
    78â†’/--
    79â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #133 (FÃ¼rediâ€“Seress improvement [FuSe94]):
    80â†’$f(n) \leq (\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} + o(1))\sqrt{n}$.
    81â†’-/
    82â†’theorem erdos133_furedi_seress :
    83â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    84â†’      (erdos133_f n : â„) â‰¤ (2 / Real.sqrt 3 + Îµ) * Real.sqrt n :=
    85â†’  sorry
    86â†’
    87â†’/--
    88â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #133 (Main question, DISPROVED [HaSe84]):
    89â†’The conjecture "$f(n)/\sqrt{n} \to \infty$" is false.
    90â†’The Hansonâ€“Seyffarth construction shows $f(n) = O(\sqrt{n})$, so the ratio
    91â†’$f(n)/\sqrt{n}$ remains bounded.
    92â†’-/
    93â†’theorem erdos133_ratio_bounded :
    94â†’    âˆƒ C : â„, 0 < C âˆ§ âˆ€á¶  n : â„• in atTop,
    95â†’      (erdos133_f n : â„) â‰¤ C * Real.sqrt n :=
    96â†’  sorry
    97â†’
    98â†’/--
    99â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #133 (Open â€” precise asymptotics):
   100â†’Both the lower bound $f(n) \geq (1 - o(1))\sqrt{n}$ and the upper bound
   101â†’$f(n) \leq (\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} + o(1))\sqrt{n}$ are known, but the precise
   102â†’asymptotic constant is unknown.  Alon conjectures $f(n) \sim \sqrt{n}$, i.e.,
   103â†’$f(n)/\sqrt{n} \to 1$.
   104â†’-/
   105â†’theorem erdos133_alon_conjecture :
   106â†’    Tendsto (fun n : â„• => (erdos133_f n : â„) / Real.sqrt n) atTop (nhds 1) :=
   107â†’  sorry
   108â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     5â†’
     6â†’open Classical
     7â†’
     8â†’/-!
     9â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #132
    10â†’
    11â†’Let $A \subset \mathbb{R}^2$ be a set of $n$ points. Must there be two
    12â†’distances which occur at least once but between at most $n$ pairs of points?
    13â†’Must the number of such distances tend to infinity as $n \to \infty$?
    14â†’
    15â†’Asked by ErdÅ‘s and Pach. A "limited-occurrence distance" for $A$ is a value
    16â†’$d > 0$ such that the number of ordered pairs $(x, y)$ with $x \neq y$ in $A$
    17â†’and $\mathrm{dist}(x, y) = d$ is between $1$ and $n = |A|$ inclusive.
    18â†’
    19â†’Hopf and Pannowitz [HoPa34] proved that the largest distance between points
    20â†’of $A$ can occur at most $n$ times, making it a limited-occurrence distance
    21â†’whenever it is realized. The question is whether a *second* such distance
    22â†’must also always exist.
    23â†’
    24â†’ErdÅ‘s believed that for $n \geq 5$ there must always exist at least two
    25â†’limited-occurrence distances. ErdÅ‘s and Fishburn [ErFi95] proved this for
    26â†’$n = 5$ and $n = 6$. Clemen, Dumitrescu, and Liu [CDL25] proved it for
    27â†’point sets in convex position.
    28â†’-/
    29â†’
    30â†’/-- For a finite point set $A \subseteq \mathbb{R}^2$ and a real value $d$,
    31â†’    the number of ordered pairs $(x, y)$ with $x \neq y$ in $A$ at
    32â†’    Euclidean distance $d$. -/
    33â†’noncomputable def pairCount (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2))) (d : â„) : â„• :=
    34â†’  ((A Ã—Ë¢ A).filter (fun p => p.1 â‰  p.2 âˆ§ dist p.1 p.2 = d)).card
    35â†’
    36â†’/-- A distance $d$ is a *limited-occurrence distance* for $A$ if it is
    37â†’    achieved by at least one but at most $|A|$ ordered pairs of distinct
    38â†’    points of $A$. -/
    39â†’def IsLimitedOccurrence (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2))) (d : â„) : Prop :=
    40â†’  0 < pairCount A d âˆ§ pairCount A d â‰¤ A.card
    41â†’
    42â†’/-- The set of all limited-occurrence distances for $A$. -/
    43â†’noncomputable def limitedOccurrences (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2))) : Set â„ :=
    44â†’  {d : â„ | IsLimitedOccurrence A d}
    45â†’
    46â†’/--
    47â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #132, Part 1 [Er84c, ErPa90, ErFi95]:
    48â†’For any set $A$ of $n \geq 5$ points in the plane $\mathbb{R}^2$, there
    49â†’must exist at least two distinct limited-occurrence distances.
    50â†’-/
    51â†’theorem erdos_problem_132_part1 :
    52â†’    âˆ€ A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2)), 5 â‰¤ A.card â†’
    53â†’      2 â‰¤ Set.ncard (limitedOccurrences A) :=
    54â†’  sorry
    55â†’
    56â†’/--
    57â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #132, Part 2 [Er84c, ErPa90]:
    58â†’The number of limited-occurrence distances must tend to infinity with $n$.
    59â†’For every $k$, there exists $N$ such that any set $A$ of at least $N$ points
    60â†’in $\mathbb{R}^2$ has at least $k$ limited-occurrence distances.
    61â†’-/
    62â†’theorem erdos_problem_132_part2 :
    63â†’    âˆ€ k : â„•, âˆƒ N : â„•, âˆ€ A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2)), N â‰¤ A.card â†’
    64â†’      k â‰¤ Set.ncard (limitedOccurrences A) :=
    65â†’  sorry
    66â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Real
     5â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Defs
     6â†’
     7â†’open Filter
     8â†’
     9â†’/-!
    10â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #131
    11â†’
    12â†’Let F(N) be the maximal size of A âŠ† {1,...,N} such that no a âˆˆ A divides
    13â†’the sum of any distinct elements of A \ {a}. Estimate F(N).
    14â†’
    15â†’The specific question "is F(N) > N^(1/2-o(1))?" has been answered NO by
    16â†’Pham and Zakharov, who proved F(N) â‰¤ N^(1/4+o(1)) via non-averaging sets.
    17â†’The correct growth rate of F(N) remains open.
    18â†’
    19â†’Known bounds:
    20â†’  N^(1/5) â‰ª F(N) â‰¤ N^(1/4+o(1))
    21â†’-/
    22â†’
    23â†’/-- A finite set A âŠ† â„• is *non-dividing* if for every a âˆˆ A and every
    24â†’    nonempty S âŠ† A \ {a}, the element a does not divide the sum âˆ‘_{s âˆˆ S} s. -/
    25â†’def IsNonDividing (A : Finset â„•) : Prop :=
    26â†’  âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, âˆ€ S : Finset â„•, S âŠ† A.erase a â†’ S.Nonempty â†’ Â¬(a âˆ£ S.sum id)
    27â†’
    28â†’/-- F(N) is the maximal cardinality of a non-dividing subset of {1,...,N}. -/
    29â†’noncomputable def erdos131F (N : â„•) : â„• :=
    30â†’  sSup {k | âˆƒ A : Finset â„•, A âŠ† Finset.Icc 1 N âˆ§ IsNonDividing A âˆ§ A.card = k}
    31â†’
    32â†’/--
    33â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #131 [Er75b, Er97b]:
    34â†’Let F(N) be the maximal size of a non-dividing subset of {1,...,N}.
    35â†’The open problem is to determine the correct polynomial growth rate of F(N).
    36â†’
    37â†’Known bounds:
    38â†’- F(N) â‰¥ c Â· N^(1/5)       (Csaba; ErdÅ‘sâ€“Levâ€“Rauzyâ€“SÃ¡ndorâ€“SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy [ELRSS99])
    39â†’- F(N) â‰¤ N^(1/4+o(1))     (Phamâ€“Zakharov [PhZa24], via non-averaging sets)
    40â†’
    41â†’This conjecture asserts that the Phamâ€“Zakharov upper bound is essentially tight:
    42â†’F(N) â‰¥ N^(1/4-Îµ) for any Îµ > 0 and all sufficiently large N.
    43â†’-/
    44â†’theorem erdos_problem_131 :
    45â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’
    46â†’      âˆ€á¶  N : â„• in atTop, (erdos131F N : â„) â‰¥ (N : â„) ^ ((1 : â„) / 4 - Îµ) :=
    47â†’  sorry
    48â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Factors
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Archimedean
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.Basic
     7â†’import Mathlib.NumberTheory.Divisors
     8â†’
     9â†’open Classical Filter Finset
    10â†’
    11â†’/-- The count of natural numbers n such that n + f(n) falls in the open real
    12â†’    interval (x, x + F(x)). Since n â‰¤ n + f(n) < x + F(x) requires n < x + F(x),
    13â†’    it suffices to search n in the range [0, x + âŒˆF xâŒ‰â‚Š]. -/
    14â†’noncomputable def shiftCount (f : â„• â†’ â„•) (F : â„• â†’ â„) (x : â„•) : â„• :=
    15â†’  ((Finset.range (x + âŒˆF xâŒ‰â‚Š + 1)).filter
    16â†’    (fun (n : â„•) => (x : â„) < (n : â„) + (f n : â„) âˆ§
    17â†’              (n : â„) + (f n : â„) < (x : â„) + F x)).card
    18â†’
    19â†’/-- The natural density of a set A âŠ† â„• is zero: the proportion of elements
    20â†’    in {0, â€¦, Nâˆ’1} belonging to A tends to 0 as N â†’ âˆ. -/
    21â†’def HasNaturalDensityZero (A : Set â„•) : Prop :=
    22â†’  Filter.Tendsto
    23â†’    (fun N : â„• => ((Finset.range N).filter (Â· âˆˆ A)).card / (N : â„))
    24â†’    Filter.atTop (nhds 0)
    25â†’
    26â†’/-- f(n)/F(n) â†’ 0 for almost all n in the natural-density sense:
    27â†’    for every Îµ > 0, the set {n : f(n)/F(n) â‰¥ Îµ} has natural density zero. -/
    28â†’def AlmostAllRatioVanishes (f : â„• â†’ â„•) (F : â„• â†’ â„) : Prop :=
    29â†’  âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’ HasNaturalDensityZero {n : â„• | Îµ â‰¤ (f n : â„) / F n}
    30â†’
    31â†’/-- The ErdÅ‘sâ€“122 property of f: for any positive F with f(n)/F(n) â†’ 0
    32â†’    in natural density, the ratio #{n âˆˆ â„• : n+f(n) âˆˆ (x, x+F(x))} / F(x)
    33â†’    is unbounded as x â†’ âˆ (equivalently, its limsup equals +âˆ). -/
    34â†’def HasErdos122Property (f : â„• â†’ â„•) : Prop :=
    35â†’  âˆ€ F : â„• â†’ â„, (âˆ€ n, 0 < F n) â†’ AlmostAllRatioVanishes f F â†’
    36â†’    âˆ€ C : â„, âˆƒá¶  x : â„• in atTop, C < (shiftCount f F x : â„) / F x
    37â†’
    38â†’/--
    39â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #122 [Er97, Er97e, EPS97] â€” OPEN
    40â†’
    41â†’For which number-theoretic functions f : â„• â†’ â„• is it true that for any
    42â†’positive function F : â„• â†’ â„ satisfying f(n)/F(n) â†’ 0 for almost all n
    43â†’(in the natural density sense), there are infinitely many x for which
    44â†’
    45â†’  #{n âˆˆ â„• : n + f(n) âˆˆ (x, x + F(x))} / F(x) â†’ âˆ?
    46â†’
    47â†’ErdÅ‘s, Pomerance, and SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy [EPS97] proved that this holds when:
    48â†’  â€¢ f(n) = Ï„(n) = number of divisors of n, and
    49â†’  â€¢ f(n) = Ï‰(n) = number of distinct prime divisors of n.
    50â†’
    51â†’ErdÅ‘s believed the property to be FALSE for:
    52â†’  â€¢ f(n) = Ï†(n)  (Euler's totient function), and
    53â†’  â€¢ f(n) = Ïƒ(n)  (sum of divisors).
    54â†’
    55â†’The full characterization of which f satisfy HasErdos122Property remains open.
    56â†’The theorem below records the two proved instances.
    57â†’-/
    58â†’theorem erdos_problem_122 :
    59â†’    HasErdos122Property (fun n => (Nat.divisors n).card) âˆ§
    60â†’    HasErdos122Property (fun n => (Nat.primeFactorsList n).toFinset.card) :=
    61â†’  sorry
    62â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Digits.Defs
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Archimedean
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Order.LiminfLimsup
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Classical
     9â†’
    10â†’/--
    11â†’The set A of non-negative integers whose base-3 representation uses only digits 0 and 1.
    12â†’Equivalently, A = {âˆ‘ Îµâ‚– Â· 3^k : Îµâ‚– âˆˆ {0,1}}.
    13â†’-/
    14â†’def baseThreeZeroOne : Set â„• :=
    15â†’  { n : â„• | âˆ€ d âˆˆ Nat.digits 3 n, d â‰¤ 1 }
    16â†’
    17â†’/--
    18â†’The set B of non-negative integers whose base-4 representation uses only digits 0 and 1.
    19â†’Equivalently, B = {âˆ‘ Îµâ‚– Â· 4^k : Îµâ‚– âˆˆ {0,1}}.
    20â†’-/
    21â†’def baseFourZeroOne : Set â„• :=
    22â†’  { n : â„• | âˆ€ d âˆˆ Nat.digits 4 n, d â‰¤ 1 }
    23â†’
    24â†’/--
    25â†’The lower asymptotic density of A âŠ† â„•:
    26â†’  d(A) = liminf_{Nâ†’âˆ} |A âˆ© {0, 1, ..., N-1}| / N
    27â†’-/
    28â†’noncomputable def lowerDensity (A : Set â„•) : â„ :=
    29â†’  Filter.liminf (fun N : â„• => ((Finset.range N).filter (Â· âˆˆ A)).card / (N : â„))
    30â†’    Filter.atTop
    31â†’
    32â†’/--
    33â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #125 (Burr, ErdÅ‘s, Graham, Li [BEGL96]):
    34â†’
    35â†’Let A = {âˆ‘ Îµâ‚– 3^k : Îµâ‚– âˆˆ {0,1}} be the set of non-negative integers with only
    36â†’digits 0 and 1 in base 3, and B = {âˆ‘ Îµâ‚– 4^k : Îµâ‚– âˆˆ {0,1}} be the set with only
    37â†’digits 0 and 1 in base 4. The conjecture is that the sumset A + B has positive
    38â†’lower density.
    39â†’
    40â†’Melfi [Me01] showed |C âˆ© [1,x]| â‰« x^0.965, improved by Haslerâ€“Melfi [HaMe24]
    41â†’to |C âˆ© [1,x]| â‰« x^0.9777, where C = A + B. Haslerâ€“Melfi also showed the
    42â†’lower density of C is at most 1015/1458 â‰ˆ 0.696.
    43â†’-/
    44â†’theorem erdos_problem_125 :
    45â†’    0 < lowerDensity (Set.image2 (Â· + Â·) baseThreeZeroOne baseFourZeroOne) :=
    46â†’  sorry
    47â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Archimedean
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Order.LiminfLimsup
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Classical
     9â†’
    10â†’/--
    11â†’The upper density of A âŠ† â„• is defined as:
    12â†’  d*(A) = limsup_{Nâ†’âˆ} |A âˆ© {0, 1, ..., N-1}| / N
    13â†’-/
    14â†’noncomputable def upperDensity (A : Set â„•) : â„ :=
    15â†’  Filter.limsup (fun N : â„• => ((Finset.range N).filter (Â· âˆˆ A)).card / (N : â„))
    16â†’    Filter.atTop
    17â†’
    18â†’/--
    19â†’ErdÅ‘s Sumset Conjecture (Problem #109) [ErGr80, p.85]:
    20â†’Any A âŠ† â„• of positive upper density contains a sumset B + C
    21â†’where both B and C are infinite.
    22â†’
    23â†’Here B + C = {b + c | b âˆˆ B, c âˆˆ C} is the sumset of B and C.
    24â†’
    25â†’Proved by Moreira, Richter, and Robertson [MRR19].
    26â†’-/
    27â†’theorem erdos_problem_109 :
    28â†’    âˆ€ A : Set â„•, 0 < upperDensity A â†’
    29â†’      âˆƒ B C : Set â„•, B.Infinite âˆ§ C.Infinite âˆ§
    30â†’        Set.image2 (Â· + Â·) B C âŠ† A :=
    31â†’  sorry
    32â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Factors
     2â†’import Mathlib.NumberTheory.Divisors
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     8â†’
     9â†’open scoped BigOperators
    10â†’open Filter
    11â†’
    12â†’/--
    13â†’For a finite set A âŠ† â„•, the pair sum product is the product of (a + b)
    14â†’over all ordered pairs of distinct elements:
    15â†’  âˆ_{a âˆˆ A} âˆ_{b âˆˆ A \ {a}} (a + b).
    16â†’This equals âˆ_{a â‰  b âˆˆ A} (a + b) ranging over ordered pairs.
    17â†’-/
    18â†’noncomputable def pairSumProduct (A : Finset â„•) : â„• :=
    19â†’  âˆ a âˆˆ A, âˆ b âˆˆ A.erase a, (a + b)
    20â†’
    21â†’/--
    22â†’The number of distinct prime factors of n (written Ï‰(n) in analytic number theory):
    23â†’  Ï‰(n) = |{p : p prime, p âˆ£ n}| = (Nat.primeFactorsList n).toFinset.card.
    24â†’-/
    25â†’noncomputable def distinctPrimeFactors (n : â„•) : â„• :=
    26â†’  (Nat.primeFactorsList n).toFinset.card
    27â†’
    28â†’/--
    29â†’f(n) is the maximal value such that for every n-element set A âŠ† â„•,
    30â†’the product âˆ_{a â‰  b âˆˆ A} (a + b) has at least f(n) distinct prime factors.
    31â†’
    32â†’Equivalently, f(n) is the minimum over all n-element subsets A âŠ† â„•
    33â†’of Ï‰(âˆ_{a â‰  b âˆˆ A} (a + b)).
    34â†’-/
    35â†’noncomputable def f (n : â„•) : â„• :=
    36â†’  sInf {k : â„• | âˆƒ A : Finset â„•, A.card = n âˆ§ distinctPrimeFactors (pairSumProduct A) = k}
    37â†’
    38â†’/--
    39â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #126 (ErdÅ‘sâ€“TurÃ¡n [ErTu34]; see also [Er95c, Er97, Er97e]) â€” OPEN
    40â†’
    41â†’Let f(n) be maximal such that if A âŠ† â„• has |A| = n then
    42â†’âˆ_{a â‰  b âˆˆ A} (a + b) has at least f(n) distinct prime factors.
    43â†’Is it true that f(n) / log n â†’ âˆ?
    44â†’
    45â†’Background: Investigated by ErdÅ‘s and TurÃ¡n in their first joint paper [ErTu34],
    46â†’prompted by a question of LÃ¡zÃ¡r and GrÃ¼nwald. They proved
    47â†’  log n â‰ª f(n) â‰ª n / log n
    48â†’where the upper bound follows by taking A = {1, ..., n}.
    49â†’It has never been proved that f(n) = o(n / log n).
    50â†’-/
    51â†’theorem erdos_problem_126 :
    52â†’    Filter.Tendsto (fun n : â„• => (f n : â„) / Real.log n) Filter.atTop Filter.atTop :=
    53â†’  sorry
    54â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Even
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     5â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’import Mathlib.Order.Interval.Finset.Nat
     8â†’
     9â†’open scoped BigOperators
    10â†’open Filter
    11â†’
    12â†’/-- A finset A has the property that no k distinct elements have a product that is
    13â†’    a perfect square. -/
    14â†’def noKSquareProduct (k : â„•) (A : Finset â„•) : Prop :=
    15â†’  âˆ€ B : Finset â„•, B âŠ† A â†’ B.card = k â†’ Â¬IsSquare (âˆ b âˆˆ B, b)
    16â†’
    17â†’/-- F k N is the size of the largest subset A of {1, ..., N} such that
    18â†’    no k distinct elements of A have a product that is a perfect square. -/
    19â†’noncomputable def F (k N : â„•) : â„• :=
    20â†’  sSup {m : â„• | âˆƒ A : Finset â„•, A âŠ† Finset.Icc 1 N âˆ§ A.card = m âˆ§ noKSquareProduct k A}
    21â†’
    22â†’/--
    23â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #121 [Er94b, Er97, Er97e, Er98] â€” DISPROVED
    24â†’
    25â†’Let F_k(N) be the size of the largest A âŠ† {1,...,N} such that the product of no k
    26â†’distinct elements of A is a perfect square.
    27â†’
    28â†’Conjectured by ErdÅ‘s, SÃ³s, and SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy [ESS95]: Is F_5(N) = (1 - o(1)) N?
    29â†’More generally, is F_{2k+1}(N) = (1 - o(1)) N for all k â‰¥ 2?
    30â†’
    31â†’Background:
    32â†’  - ErdÅ‘sâ€“SÃ³sâ€“SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy [ESS95] proved F_2(N) = (6/Ï€Â² + o(1)) N and F_3(N) = (1 - o(1)) N,
    33â†’    and F_k(N) â‰ N / log N for all even k â‰¥ 4.
    34â†’  - ErdÅ‘s [Er38] proved F_4(N) = o(N) (in particular, density 0 for k = 4).
    35â†’
    36â†’This was answered in the NEGATIVE by Tao [Ta24], who proved that for any k â‰¥ 4 there
    37â†’exists a constant c_k > 0 such that F_k(N) â‰¤ (1 - c_k + o(1)) N. Thus the density of
    38â†’the largest such set is bounded strictly away from 1 for all k â‰¥ 4, disproving the
    39â†’conjecture for all odd k â‰¥ 5.
    40â†’
    41â†’The theorem below formalizes Tao's result.
    42â†’-/
    43â†’theorem erdos_problem_121 :
    44â†’    âˆ€ k : â„•, 4 â‰¤ k â†’
    45â†’    âˆƒ c : â„, 0 < c âˆ§
    46â†’      âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’
    47â†’        âˆ€á¶  N : â„• in atTop, (F k N : â„) â‰¤ (1 - c + Îµ) * N :=
    48â†’  sorry
    49â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Sqrt
     6â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     7â†’
     8â†’open Real Filter
     9â†’
    10â†’/--
    11â†’For a finite simple graph G and a vertex subset S, the cut defined by S
    12â†’consists of edges with exactly one endpoint in S. We count these as ordered pairs
    13â†’(v, w) with v âˆˆ S, w âˆ‰ S, and G.Adj v w; since G.Adj is symmetric and S and Sá¶œ
    14â†’are disjoint, each undirected cut edge is counted exactly once (from its S-side endpoint).
    15â†’-/
    16â†’noncomputable def cutSize {V : Type*} [DecidableEq V] [Fintype V]
    17â†’    (G : SimpleGraph V) [DecidableRel G.Adj] (S : Finset V) : â„• :=
    18â†’  ((Finset.univ Ã—Ë¢ Finset.univ).filter fun p : V Ã— V =>
    19â†’    p.1 âˆˆ S âˆ§ p.2 âˆ‰ S âˆ§ G.Adj p.1 p.2).card
    20â†’

    22â†’The maximum bipartite subgraph size of G: the maximum over all vertex bipartitions
    23â†’(S, Sá¶œ) of the number of edges crossing the cut. This equals the maximum number of
    24â†’edges in any bipartite subgraph of G (the max-cut).

    26â†’noncomputable def maxBipartiteSubgraphSize {V : Type*} [DecidableEq V] [Fintype V]
    27â†’    (G : SimpleGraph V) [DecidableRel G.Adj] : â„• :=
    28â†’  Finset.univ.sup (cutSize G)
    29â†’
    30â†’/--
    31â†’The Edwards lower bound: every graph with m edges has a bipartite subgraph of size at
    32â†’least m/2 + (âˆš(8m+1) âˆ’ 1)/8. Proved by Edwards [Ed73].
    33â†’-/
    34â†’noncomputable def edwardsLB (m : â„•) : â„ :=
    35â†’  (m : â„) / 2 + (Real.sqrt (8 * (m : â„) + 1) - 1) / 8
    36â†’
    37â†’/--
    38â†’f(m) is the maximal value r such that every finite simple graph with m edges has a
    39â†’bipartite subgraph with at least edwardsLB(m) + r edges. Equivalently, f(m) is the
    40â†’infimum over all finite simple graphs G with exactly m edges of the excess
    41â†’  maxBipartiteSubgraphSize(G) âˆ’ edwardsLB(m).
    42â†’
    43â†’Edwards [Ed73] proved f(m) â‰¥ 0 for all m. Note that f(C(n,2)) = 0, achieved by Kâ‚™.
    44â†’-/
    45â†’noncomputable def f (m : â„•) : â„ :=
    46â†’  sInf {r : â„ | âˆƒ (V : Type) (_ : Fintype V) (_ : DecidableEq V)
    47â†’    (G : SimpleGraph V) (_ : DecidableRel G.Adj),
    48â†’    G.edgeFinset.card = m âˆ§ r = (maxBipartiteSubgraphSize G : â„) - edwardsLB m}
    49â†’
    50â†’/--
    51â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #127 (ErdÅ‘sâ€“Kohayakawaâ€“GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s; solved by Alon [Al96]):
    52â†’Let f(m) be maximal such that every graph with m edges contains a bipartite subgraph with
    53â†’at least m/2 + (âˆš(8m+1) âˆ’ 1)/8 + f(m) edges.
    54â†’There exists an infinite sequence of integers (máµ¢) with máµ¢ â†’ âˆ such that f(máµ¢) â†’ âˆ.
    55â†’
    56â†’Edwards [Ed73] proved f(m) â‰¥ 0 for all m.
    57â†’Alon [Al96] proved this in the affirmative: f(nÂ²/2) â‰« n^(1/2).
    58â†’Alon [Al96] also showed the upper bound f(m) â‰ª m^(1/4) for all m.
    59â†’-/
    60â†’theorem erdos_problem_127 :
    61â†’    âˆƒ (seq : â„• â†’ â„•), StrictMono seq âˆ§
    62â†’      Filter.Tendsto (fun i => f (seq i)) Filter.atTop Filter.atTop :=
